prompt.body:
Je bent op bezoek geweest bij je tante in haar nieuwe huis. Je stuurt je penvriend(in) er een e-mail over.

  • Vertel welke kleur de woonkamer is.
  • Noem twee dingen die je tante in de woonkamer heeft.
  • Vertel nog iets over het huis. Bedenk dit zelf.
  • Vertel wat je het leukst vindt aan het nieuwe huis.
  • Vul je naam in.

prompt.body:
Lees de tekst. Beantwoord de vraag.

An escaped elephant

An elephant has escaped from the local zoo.

Workers at the zoo say that the animal probably walked out of its cage during feeding time this evening. They didn't notice the animal was missing until about twenty minutes later. By that time, it had left the zoo grounds and caused chaos in the streets.

Animal welfare officers are now trying to catch the elephant. Until then, the public is warned not to come near it.

1. Wanneer is dit bericht geschreven?

content.body: op het moment dat de olifant nog los rondliep op straat bij de dierentuin
toen de mensen van de dierentuin ontdekten dat er een olifant weg was
vlak nadat de ontsnapte olifant door de dierenbescherming was gevangen

prompt.body:
Lees de tekst. Kies het goede antwoord.

Blue whale

The blue whale is the largest animal to have ever lived on Earth. Blue whales are even larger than the largest dinosaur! The biggest blue whales can become 100 feet long, which is longer than three school buses put together.

Even though blue whales are huge, they eat very small creatures: krill. Krill are tiny shrimp-like animals. The whale simply opens its mouth, fills it with krill and salt water, and filters the water out of its mouth. The blue whale can eat over 8,000 pounds of krill in a single day!

1. Hoe groot kan de blauwe vinvis worden?

content.body: groter dan elk dier dat ooit op aarde heeft geleefd
kleiner dan een dinosauriër, maar groter dan een schoolbus

How big is your family?

Rebecca, Australia:
There are four people in my family: my mother, my father, my younger brother and myself. I actually don't live with my family anymore. I live in a country town three hours away, so I don't get to see my family very much. At the moment, we have two dogs as well, which is nice.

Swinki, South Africa:
I'm the youngest in a family with five childen. But my sister, who is a year older than me, has a baby, so you could say that there are six kids in the family. My whole family lives in Kenya. I'm the only one who lives abroad. My brothers and sisters and I hated each other when we were little, now we are very close. I love them and I miss them a lot!

prompt.body:
Je gaat je penvriend(in) een e-mail schrijven over je familie.

  • Zeg hoi tegen je penvriend(in).
  • Vraag hoe het met hem/haar gaat en vertel hoe het met jou gaat.
  • Vertel waar je over gaat schrijven.
  • Vertel bij wie je woont: je moeder, je vader, allebei of bij iemand anders.
  • Vertel hoeveel broers en zussen je hebt.
  • Vertel wie je favoriete familielid is. (My favourite family member is...)
  • Vertel hoe oud diegene is en wat voor werk hij/zij doet.
  • Vertel wat zijn of haar hobby's zijn.
  • Stel een zelfbedachte vraag.
  • Zeg je vriend(in) gedag.
  • Sluit af met je naam.

values.value:
Je hebt het goed gedaan als:

  • je de juiste woorden hebt gebruikt.
  • alle punten uit de opdracht in je e-mail staan.
  • je de e-mail bent begonnen en geëindigd zoals het hoort.

Voorbeeld:

Hi!

How are you?
I am fine.
I am going to tell you about my family.
I live with my mum.
I have two brothers and one sister.
My favourite family member is my uncle Jermaine.
He is 35 years old and he is a truck driver.
He likes football and rap music.
Who is your favourite family member?

Bye for now,
Karim

Lees de tekst en beantwoord de vragen.

Where are you from?

Tom: Hi, I don't think we've met. My name's Tom.
Nita: Hi, Tom. Nice to meet you. My name is Juanita, but everybody calls me Nita.
Tom: Nice to meet you, Nita. So, where are you from?
Nita: Originally, I'm from Argentina, but we moved to the United States when I was about five years old. How about you?
Tom: I was born in Fresno, California and we lived there until I was seven. But my father worked for the army, so we moved all over the place.

How often do you go shopping?

Hello, I am Geaw from Thailand. So you'd like to know how often I go shopping? Well, not that often, to be honest.

I do go to the supemarket for my groceries and other things that I need for my everyday life, but as for shopping as in going to the city centre and walking in and out of stores looking for clothes and shoes and stuff... Nah, I don't really like that.

The only thing I go to the High Street for is books, because I love reading and I love looking at all kinds of books. They're expensive though, so I don't buy them very often. But that's not really shopping, is it?

Are you a good student?

Hi, my name is Win and I'm from Vietnam. Today I'm answering the question: are you a good student?

It all depends on what period of time we're talking about. For my education I have been to elementary school, junior high and high school.

In elementary school I was a really good student. I was enthusiastic about everything and I got really good grades.

That changed when I got to junior high. I guess I got a bit lazy, and I only worked hard on the subjects that interested me the most. That only got worse as I got to high school.

Right now I'm studying to be an electrician. It's a very happy time for me, and I try harder with my education than ever before. That's because I'm studying something that I'm really interested in.

So am I a good student? I guess the answer is: it depends on what I'm studying!

  1. Welke vraag moet Win beantwoorden?
  2. Waar hangt het antwoord van af?
  3. Op welke schoolsoort was Win nog enthousiast en leergierig?
  4. Wanneer doet Win haar best op school?

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.
Lees de tekst en beantwoord de vragen.

Test Taking Skills

Taking tests is a skill you can learn. Do you freeze up when a teacher says it's time for a test? Do you get so nervous that you make stupid mistakes? Use these steps and your test scores will go up in all subjects!

1. Do your homework and go to class. This way you will know the material and you won't have so much reason to be afraid.

2. Sleep well the night before. Study in the afternoon, then relax in the evening. Eat a good breakfast. You need to be strong and refreshed to do your best.

3. Bring paper, pen, pencil, eraser, a watch, and your textbook or dictionary if they are allowed.

4. Read the instructions two times. Read the questions well before you answer.

5. Breathe. When you start to get anxious, put your pencil down on the table, close your eyes and count to 10. Only when you are relaxed can you do your best.

School students do not shower after sports class

A report has found out that more than half of high school boys and two-thirds of girls never shower after a P.E. class.

Researchers suggest that students don't want to sweat and take a shower, so they are less active in sports classes.

The BBC says the study did not look at the exact reasons why the students did not shower after PE. Undressing in front of classmates may be too much for some children.

Pamela Naylor, spokeswoman for a health organisation in England, said many children had concerns about their body image and that schools needed to address this.

She said: "Schools, workplaces and local authorities all have a role to play in shifting attitudes so that physical activity, and what comes with it, like sweating and the need for showering, is encouraged and accommodated."

1. Wat is het probleem?

content.body: De douches op scholen werken vaak niet.
Jongeren sporten en zweten veel te weinig.
Veel jongeren willen niet douchen na het sporten.

Big Wave Tour in Mexico

Twelve surfers advance to the semi-finals after successfully taking on the giant waves of the Big Wave Tour Puerto Escondido Challenge in Mexico.

Competing against each other and nature, the surfers wrestled with the huge waves, and it was Americans Will Skudin, Makuakai Rothman, Greg Long, and Australian Jamie Mitchell who topped the leaderboard. Mitchell recorded the highest score of the day with a perfect 10 after surviving a barrel ride through one of the mighty waves.

The Puerto Escondido Challenge is the first event of the World's Surf League Big Wave Tour, which consists of 6 events that will take place between now and February of next year. And riding those surfs is no mean feat - waves must reach at least 20 feet (6 metres) in height for an event to take place. That's got to take some guts.

Do you eat much fast food?

Hi, my name is Erina and I'm from Japan.

I was raised in a family that was very strict about food, so I wasn't really allowed to eat fast food. My parents have always cooked for me, and they always use fresh ingredients. Plus, they're both good cooks, so I feel very fortunate!

Even for breakfast, we often have rice with fish and lots of vegetables, so you could say I'm on a very healthy diet.

When I grew older, I started hanging out with friends, and obviously, we would go to fast food restaurants sometimes. I would of course go along, and it was fun, but I didn't really like the food! I think it's because of the diet I'm used to. I simply don't crave fast food.

Children's bad teeth

A dentist in the UK had to take out all a child's baby teeth because they were rotten. Unfortunately, this two-year-old is not the only one with such problems.

A whole generation of children in the UK is affected. In one year, dentists had to remove teeth from as many as 14,000 children aged 5 and under. Not only did this cost the National Health Service a lot of money, removing baby teeth also leads to more problems later in a child's life.

The cause of all those rotten teeth is unhealthy food. Children wat too much processed food and drink too many sugary, fizzy drinks.

Doctors say that the parents need to be better informed, so that they understand what not to give to their children.

Best Holiday
Three students answer the question: What is your country's best holiday?

Phoebe from China
I think in China the best holiday is the spring festival.
It is the main festival in China and it is also called Chinese new year. On this day, families always get together and the children get their red pack, which is an envelope with money put in. We also eat little pastries called moon cakes. Everybody likes that holiday.

Kat from Germany
In my home country, Germany, I think the best holiday is Christmas. The Christmas season is amazing. The best thing about Christmas are the seasonal markets where you can buy all kinds of delicious food.
Christmas time normally comes with a lot of snow and an amazing atmosphere.
My mom makes cookies, and we have lots of friends and family over to our house, so it's a wonderful time.

Antoinette from United States
I'm from the U.S., so I would say the best holiday would be Thanksgiving.
Although there are some aspects of that holiday that I don't like.
I don't like the overeating, but I do like the fact that families get together.
At the dinner table we talk about what we're thankful for that year.

Rick: "Hi! It's a nice day, isn't it."
Alexis: "Yes. It is a beautiful day."

Rick: "Do you live around here or are you visiting?"
Alexis: "I am on vacation from Korea."

Rick: "That's cool. Are you having a good time?"
Alexis: "Yes. There are many things to see and I'm taking a lot of pictures. Do you live in this city?"

Rick: "Yeah. I'm just here with my parents. They wanted to come to the park today."
Alexis: "What's a good place to visit in this city?"

Rick: "Where have you been so far?"
Alexis: "This was my first stop. I am going to visit the Natural History Museum with a friend tomorrow."

Rick: "I recommend going to the water front downtown. They have a ferry you can ride, some good restaurants, and a good beach for a walk."
Alexis: "How do I get there from here?"

Rick: "You see Jackson street over there? Go straight for 10 blocks. When you see 5th Avenue, turn left. Follow the street for about 3 miles and you should see it."
Alexis: "Thanks. I'll go check it out. It was nice talking to you."

Rick: "It was nice meeting you. Have a good time."

  1. Waar wilden de ouders van Rick graag heen?
  2. Waar gaat Alexis morgen heen?
  3. Wat is volgens Rick een aanrader om te bezoeken?
  4. Wat moet Alexis doen zodra hij 5th Avenue ziet?

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

Home is where the heart is.

"Home is where the heart is" is a popular saying. I really like this saying because it is so true. When you are growing up, home is where your family lives. But when you move away, this changes. I left home when I was 18 and slowly my childhood home was no longer. Now it's my parents' house and not my home.

Since I've left my parent's home, I have moved around a lot. I only spent a year or so in most places I lived in and they never really felt like home.

In my opinion, a home is somewhere you feel totally relaxed and where you want to return to every night.

The expression "Home Sweet Home" is also true. You have to have nice feelings about the place where you live to call it home.

I am moving to a new flat next month and I really hope that place will feel like home.

Facebook

Facebook is a social networking service and website started by Mark Zuckerberg in February 2004 when he was still a student. Starting the website wasn't easy as it was shut down by Harvard University multiple times. The website was originally only accessible for students of Harvard University. In the following years, students from other university were able to use the website. In 2006 the website became available for the public.

After registering to use the site, users may create a personal profile, add other users as friends, exchange messages, post status updates and photos, and receive notifications when others update their profiles.

Nowadays, Facebook has millions of users and the company also owns other social media websites, like Instagram and Whatsapp.

Why British tabloids are so extreme

Sensation sells. The British tabloid papers know this all too well. The British press has accumulated so much power they can do whatever they want. Exaggerating the number of deaths in the 17th century English civil war, fake news reports about famous serial killer Jack the ripper and stalking Prince Harry and Megan; they've done it all. Somehow, tabloid papers manage to combine politics, sports and gossip so seamlessly together that readers don't even question the lies they are told and this is a problem.

You might wonder: how are they able to do this? Is it even allowed to print lies about other people's lives. The answer is money. These papers are so rich they can afford to bribe people to either keep their mouths shut or give them false information and hire the best lawyers when they get sued.

Kate: I fell in love with my first boyfriend when I was 14.

Anne: OK, so how did you meet him?

Kate: We met through mutual friends.

Kate: We went to the cinema. Afterwards we went to the bar to have a drink.

Anne: So, were your parents cool with you having a boyfriend?

Anne: Are you still in love with him?

Kate: No, unfortunately we broke up.

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.
Lees de tekst en beantwoord de vragen.

Friends fight

Last night I got into a huge fight with my best friend Thom. We were at a party at another friend's house. He wanted to leave, but I didn't because my crush was there too. This was my chance to talk to her. She was finally paying attention to me when my friend started to pull me towards the door. "Come on Kevin! I want to leave." He said. I'm not proud of it, but I snapped. At first, I just raised my voice, but then he started to shout. We called each other names and said horrible things to each other that we didn't mean. At one point, I even pushed him. I can't believe I did that. I really regret it. One of our other friends came between us and stopped the fight. Thom left and I felt horrible. I didn't want to fight, I just wanted to stay at the party and impress my crush.

This morning, I called Thom to apologize. He was hurt by all the things I had said in the heat of the moment, but he accepted my apology. I also told him that I should have gone home with him. It turns out that Thom wanted to leave because his ex was at the party with her new boyfriend. He didn't tell me because she was ashamed that he still had feelings for her. So, we came up with a plan. In the future, we will always tell each other the truth, and we will always listen to each other's point of view without getting mad.


1 Waarom wilde Kevin (de schrijver) niet naar huis?

2 Wie begon de ruzie?

3 Waarom wilde Thom naar huis?

4 Wat gaan Kevin en Thom in het vervolg doen om ruzies te voorkomen?

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.

Doctor's office

I was feeling a little ill the other day. So, the next day, I decided the next day to visit my doctor before things got worse. I called the doctor in the morning, and I made an appointment for 9:30 a.m.

When I arrived at the doctor's office, the nurse gave me some forms: I had to fill out some insurance paperwork and a form describing my current medical condition, along with the symptoms I was feeling.

After a few minutes, the nurse called my name and took me back to one of their examination rooms.

The nurse checked my vital signs including my temperature and blood pressure, and then I waited until the doctor came in.

After the examination he asked me a few questions and the doctor's diagnosis was that I had a bacterial infection.

She wrote me a prescription for some medication, which I was supposed to take two times a day.

After the examination by the doctor, I went to the pharmacy to pick up the medicine. Then I went home with my medicine and went to bed, because I still felt sick.

prompt.body:
Read the text and answer the questions.
Lees de tekst en beantwoord de vragen.

Healthy habits

Developing healthy habits such as eating healthy and exercising helps protect you from physical and mental problems. You'll feel and function better and feel healthier. Here are some examples of healthy habits.

1. Eat breakfast every day
Breakfast is the "most important meal of the day." You need it to replenish the supply of glucose your body lost overnight. A healthy morning meal provides the nutrients needed for your brain and body to function well.

2. Drink enough water
Drinking plenty of water helps remove toxins from your body and replaces fluids lost through sweat and urine. Water also improves the movement of nutrients and oxygen to your cells. Drink 8 glasses of water a day, as recommended by doctors, to stay hydrated and keep your body functioning well.

3. Keep yourself active
You don't have to go to the gym to exercise. Keeping your body moving is considered exercise. Physical movement increases blood circulation, burns calories, and helps maintain heart health. Take the stairs up instead of the elevator or get up and move around your house or workplace every 30 minutes.

[adapted from https://www.developgoodhabits.com/healthy-habits/]

Elephants retire from a circus

It's described as 'the Greatest Show on Earth'. But now, after 145 years as the centrepiece of the Ringling Brothers' Circus travelling across the United States, the show's last remaining 11 elephants have arrived at a conservation centre in Florida to officially retire.

Meet Asia, the 48-year-old veteran entertainer who spent decades delighting crowds. She, and the other remaining 10, will spend their days outside from now on.

"It's been in the sense that after 145 years our elephants will no longer be a part of our travelling circus shows. It's the end of an era, its sweet in a sense and at the end of the day, it's about these magnificent creatures and conservation, and ensuring that these guys will be around for many generations to come."

Fewer than 40,000 elephants remain in the wild. Two hundred and fifty are in captivity in the United States, 39 of which are now at this 200-acre centre. The endangered Asian elephants have spent most of their lives in front of crowds of people, but while many may see this as an end of an era, others would argue it's time for a well-earned rest.

New York

New York is a in the Northeastern region of the States. New York is the 27th most extensive, the 3rd most populous, and the 7th most densely populated of the 50 United States.

New York is bordered by New Jersey and Pennsylvania to the south, and by Connecticut, Massachusetts and Vermont to the east.

The state has a maritime with Rhode Island east of Long Island, as well as an international border with the Canadian provinces of Ontario to the west and north, and Quebec to the north.

The state of New York is often referred to as New York State to distinguish it from City.

New York City, with a population of over 8.1 million, is the most city in the United States.

It is known for its status as a centre for and culture and for its status as the largest gateway for immigration to the United States.

According to the U.S. Department of , it is also a destination of choice for many foreign .

Both the state and city were named for the 17th century Duke of York, James Stuart, future James II and of England and Scotland.

The blue whale is the largest animal to have ever lived on Earth. Blue whales are even larger than the largest dinosaur! The biggest blue whales can become 100 feet long, which is longer than three school buses put together.

Even though blue whales are huge, they eat very small creatures: krill. Krill are tiny shrimp-like animals. The whale simply opens its mouth, fills it with krill and salt water, and filters the water out of its mouth. The blue whale can eat over 8,000 pounds of krill in a single day!

prompt.body:
What are the differences between British English and American English words?
In the next exercise match the English words with the American words.

Read the telephone conversation below and answer the question.

A: "Hello? This is Steve."
B: "Hi Steve, this is Mary from ABC Company. I'm returning your call."

A: "Hi Mary. How are you doing?"
B: "I'm doing great thanks."

A: "Thanks for returning my call. I couldn't figure out why the ending balance on fiscal year 2003 didn't match the beginning balance on 2004."
B: "When I checked, it was matching. How much is the difference?"

A: "The amount is exactly $42,000."
B: "Oh. I know what the problem is. We opened another bank account at the end of fiscal year 2003. I might not have included the new bank statements when I sent over the information."

A: "That makes sense. I'm just glad it wasn't out of my miscalculation. Can you send over the statements? I should be done by end of day since everything looks good."
B: "Sure. I'll fax them to you immediately. Is 555-123-4567 the number I should fax it to?"

A: "Yes. That is the correct number."
B: "I'll do it right now."

A: "Thank you for your help."
B: "I should have sent them over to you the first time. I apologize for that."

A: "No problem."
B: "Thank you."

A: "Thank you. Bye."

Word list:
balance - saldo
fiscal year - begrotingsjaar
bank statements - bankafschriften

  1. Hoe heet persoon A?
  2. Hoe heet persoon B?
  3. Wat is het probleem van persoon A?
  4. Wat is de oorzaak van dit probleem, volgens persoon B?
  5. Wat gaat persoon B doen, om ervoor te zorgen dat persoon A het probleem op kan lossen?

Very special wedding dress

Shopping for a wedding dress can be both challenging and time-consuming, and with wedding season upon us, we thought we'd show you a more creative alternative.

Welcome to the 12th annual toilet paper wedding dress contest. Yes, that's dresses made out of, you guessed it, toilet paper. The annual competition offers a more creative twist to bridal attire and the competitors were flushed with excitement as they made it down to the final 10 out of 1,500 hopefuls.

The designers were only allowed to use toilet paper, glue, tape, needles and thread to create their masterpieces. The winning dress dubbed "Winter Last" was inspired by the creator's first snowstorm experience.

"I was what happens when you have a winter wedding? It's beautiful. What would you wear? So I definitely developed a snow queen kind of attire."

The creation will be on display at one of Ripley's Believe It or Not global locations and with the ten-thousand-dollar prize, this is one you may want to try at home.

Lees de volgende tekst. Na het lezen van de tekst beantwoord je de vragen.

Are you a good student?

Hi, my name is Win, I'm from Vietnam and my question is whether I am a good student or not?

Read the text below and answer the questions (in English).

Test Taking Skills

Test taking is a skill you can learn. Do you freeze up when a teacher says it's time for a test? Do you get so nervous that you make stupid mistakes? Unlearning test anxiety takes mental discipline. Study the following steps and your test scores will go up in all subjects!

  1. Do your homework and go to class. This way you will know the material and won't have as much reason to be afraid.
  2. Sleep well the night before. Review the material in the afternoon, then relax in the evening. Eat a good breakfast. You need to be strong and refreshed to do your best.
  3. Come prepared with paper, pen, pencil, eraser, a watch, and book or dictionary if they are allowed.
  4. Read the instructions twice. Read the questions well before you answer.
  5. Breathe. When you feel yourself start to get anxious, put your pencil down on the table, out of your hand, close your eyes, and count to 10. If you think you don't have time, remember that if you're anxious, you can't think well and will make stupid mistakes. Only relaxed can you do your best.

Afternoon Tea and High Tea in England.

Afternoon Tea
The afternoon tea is traditionally at 4 o'clock. Afternoon tea is not common these days because most of the people are working at that time. However, you can still have afternoon tea at the many tea rooms in England. Traditionally it consists of tea (or coffee) served with sweet and savoury snacks.

High Tea
The high tea was traditionally at 6 o'clock. Nowadays people call it the evening meal, dinner or supper.
The working population did not have afternoon tea. They had a meal about midday, and a meal after work, between five and seven o'clock. This meal was called 'high tea' or just 'tea'.
It was traditionally a substantial meal with delicious sweet foods and savoury snacks ( = hartige hapjes.

Twenty-four bridges span the Thames in London.

London Bridge
The oldest bridge is the London Bridge, which was originally made from wood. In 1209 it was replaced by a stone bridge with shops and houses along its sides. This was followed by a granite bridge in 1831, and the present concrete bridge in 1973.

Tower Bridge
Tower Bridge has stood over the River Thames in London since 1894.
You see this famous bridge often in motives and in tourist information about London.
Tower Bridge is the only Thames bridge which can be raised.
It used to be raised about 50 times a day, but nowadays it is only raised 4 to 5 times a week.

April Fool's Day

April Fool's Day started in the sixteenth century in Europe. Before that time, New Year's Day was celebrated on April 1st. Then a new calendar was introduced called the Gregorian calendar. January 1st became the first day of the year, but many people did not know about it. So those who continued to celebrate New Year's Day on April 1st were teased. They were called fools.

Nowadays we play jokes on people on April 1st. For example, someone might put salt in the sugar container so another person could "accidentally" put it in their coffee. Or someone might change the time on another person's alarm clock so that person would unknowingly wake up earlier or later than planned. Or maybe a person would tell a lie to make someone else shocked.

After we play the trick, we say "April Fool." Then the poor person realizes he was fooled. It is generally done in the spirit of fun and doesn't cause any real harm to anyone. Do you have any great jokes to play on anyone today? Try it out. Just don't forget to say "April Fool" when the other person begins looking a little confused.

prompt.body:
Lees de volgende tekst. Na het lezen van de tekst beantwoord je de vragen.

Houses with names

ouse naming started many years ago with rich people naming their homes.
The rich people named their Halls, Houses, Manors, Castles, and Lodges according to ancestry (voorouders), location and family titles. Think of:

  • Norfolk House (Duke of);
  • Belvoir Castle (overlooking the Belvoir Valley);
  • Windsor Castle.

Little by little other people began over the years to give names to their homes.
All houses in towns and cities have a number. A few houses outside the city only have a name.

prompt.body:
Homestay or University Dormitories

When many international students move overseas to study English, they often have to decide whether to live on campus in a dormitory (= slaapzaal), or stay with a host family.
However, each comes with its benefits and challenges.
Some international students prefer to live with a homestay family when they study in a foreign country.
There are a number of companies that could help students find homestay opportunities.
When doing homestay, get involved with the host family as much as possible. Volunteer to help around the house. Be a part of the family.

Can you think of three advantages and three disadvantages of a homestaying situation?

values.value:
Advantages:

  1. More silence, better for concentration to study.
  2. You will be taken care of.
  3. More family coziness.

​Disadvantages:

  1. Less contact with study mates.
  2. Further away from school.
  3. You have to keep the rules of the house.
